article.headline: Colorado 95, Idaho State 65
article.story:
BOULDER, Colo. (AP) -- Players hoisted coach Ceal Barry on their
shoulders and fans waved gold placards bearing the No. 400 after
she posted her 400th victory at Colorado on Friday night.

Tera Bjorklund had 23 points and 14 rebounds, and No. 20
Colorado defeated Idaho State 95-65 in an opening-round game of the
Coors Classic.

Colorado (4-1) will meet California, a 66-47 winner over Lehigh,
in the championship game Saturday night.

"Four hundred wins is impressive," Bjorklund said. "It just
shows her dedication and loyalty to the program. We're just glad we
got to recognize her for that."

Overall, it was the 483rd win of Barry's career.

Randie Wirt added 17 points, Veronica Johns-Richardson 16 and
Kate Fagan 14 for the Buffaloes, who outshot Idaho State 48 percent
to 36 percent.

Lindy Whitley scored 16 points and Molly Hays had 10 points and
17 rebounds for the Bengals (2-1), who made only one of five free
throws compared to Colorado's 22-of-30.

"I felt like it was one of our more consistent games from start
to finish," Barry said. "We knew coming into the game that they
shot really well from the 3-point line, so we wanted to get in on
(Whitley) and force something else to happen.

"Offensively, we ran the floor pretty well and executed the
triangle as well as we have all season."

The Buffaloes used a 10-0 run early in the second half to
produce a 61-43 lead.

Fagan had five points during the flurry, including a three-point
play, and Johns-Richardson fed Bjorklund and Fagan on back-to-back
layups.

Fagan's fast-break layup capped a 6-0 run and made it 70-50 with
9:17 left, and the Bengals got no closer than 18 points after that.

"We had too many turnovers (20) and got off to a rocky start,"
Idaho State coach Jon Newlee said. "I think the nerves of playing
a top-20 team took over at the start. We are undersized, and in the
second half they took it to us and exploited it.

"We need to play better defense. If you have defensive
breakdowns against a top-20 team, you are going to pay for it."

Wirt scored four points and freshman Emily Waner hit a 3-pointer
from the corner to highlight a 9-0 spurt that gave Colorado a 19-6
lead early in the first half.

Bjorklund scored five straight Colorado points to help the Buffs
take a 34-19 lead.

Idaho State countered with 11 straight points, including a pair
of 3-pointers by Whitley, to cut the deficit to 34-30. Colorado
pushed the lead back to 45-35 at halftime.
